title: Citizenship in India (Part II of the Constitution)

information.title: Constitutional Provisions
information.description: Articles 5 to 11 in Part II of the Indian Constitution deal with citizenship. The Constitution provides for single citizenship for the entire country.

information.title: Citizenship Act, 1955
information.description: This Act provides for acquisition and determination of Indian citizenship. It has been amended several times, with the most recent significant amendment in 2019.

information.title: Acquisition of Citizenship
information.description: Indian citizenship can be acquired by birth, descent, registration, naturalization, and incorporation of territory. The specific conditions for each method are detailed in the Citizenship Act.

information.title: Overseas Citizenship of India (OCI)
information.description: OCI is a form of permanent residency available to people of Indian origin and their spouses. It provides most of the rights of full citizens except for voting rights and government employment.

information.title: Loss of Citizenship
information.description: Indian citizenship can be lost through renunciation, termination, or deprivation as per the provisions of the Citizenship Act.

information.title: Dual Citizenship
information.description: India does not allow dual citizenship. Acquiring citizenship of another country leads to automatic loss of Indian citizenship, except for minors who can hold dual citizenship until the age of 18.
